$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 429-41-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 66-71-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of a Nitrogen- Containing
Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of nitrogen-containing
heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2 (0.6 mmol), cubic
Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline (L2; 10-20 mol%), and
TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48 h until complete
consumption of the starting material was observed (monitored by TLC).
After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was poured into the
mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5 mL) and extracted
with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then dried (anhyd Na2SO4)
and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was purified by flash column
chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford the desired product.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (3)5d, yield 100%. 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 8.40 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 8.01 (s, 1 H), 7.61 (d, J = 8.8
Hz, 2 H), 7.41 (s, 1 H), 7.29 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
146.5, 142.0, 135.4, 131.8, 125.7, 121.1, 117.6. LRMS (EI, 70 eV): m/z
(%) = 189 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on copper catalyst and ligand, nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst,
optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tang, Bo-Xiao; Guo, Sheng-Mei; Zhang, Man-Bo; Li, Jin-Heng
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (11), 1707-1716

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME1 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (3)5d, yield 100%. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.40 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 8.01 (s, 1 H), 7.61
(d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 7.41 (s, 1 H), 7.29 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (125 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 146.5, 142.0, 135.4, 131.8, 125.7, 121.1, 117.6. LRMS (EI, 70
eV): m/z (%) = 189 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on copper catalyst and ligand, nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst,
optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system

$DATUM 1306-05-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM A typical procedure for N-arylation of imidazole with chloroarenes In a
typical experimental procedure, chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole
(81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium
tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in case of electron rich chloroarenes only)
and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg) were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for
36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst was filtered and the filtrate was quenched
with aqueous sodium hydrogen carbonate and the product was extracted with
ethyl acetate. The combined organic extracts were dried over anhydrous
sodium sulfate and filtered. Solvent was evaporated under reduced
pressure and concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude
product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl
acetate, 70/30) to afford the N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1,
entry 9,). The known coupling products are well compared with the
reported spectral data and melting points. For the new compounds HRMS
data are included. 1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole 1)
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 1, entry 1). M.p. 203 °C; 1H NMR
(300 MHZ (CDCl3): δ= 8.37 (d, J= 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.93 (br s, 1H), 7.58 (d, J
= 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.32 (br s, 1H), 7.24 (br s, 1H ).; EI-MS: 189 (100%),
159, 141, 116, 89, 50; GC/MS: tR = 23.843 min; m/z : 189.25.; HRMS:
calcd.for C9H7N3O2 .189.053, found 189.053.; IR: (KBr) cm-1 ; 3130.96,
1599.57, 1528.72, 1340.33, 1052.66, 854.85.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Design and Evolution of Copper Apatite Catalysts for N-Arylation of
Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Choudary, Boyapati M.; Sridhar, Chidara; Kantam, Mannepalli L.; Venkanna,
Gopaldasu T.; Sreedhar, Bojja
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127(28), 9948-9949

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A
flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged
with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand (0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0
mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl
halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced
with a glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back
filled with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room
temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was
then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (7t)
2 Following the general procedure, imidazole (0.068 g, 1.0 mmol) was
coupled with 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.189 g, 1.2 mmol) in the presence
of ligand 4a. The crude product was purified over a silica gel column
using ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give a pale yellow solid (98%
yield). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.30 (s, 1H), 7.39 (s, 1H), 7.59 (d, J
= 9.0 Hz, 2H), 8.04 (s, 1H), 8.39 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (150
MHz, CDCl3): δ 117.6, 121.0, 125.7, 131.7, 135.4, 141.9, 146.2 ppm. GC-MS
(EI, m/z): 189 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM To prepare substituted imidazoles, NaH (60% in oil, 420 mg, 10.5 mmol)
was added to a DMF solution of imidazole (A1) (680 mg, 10 mmol) at 0°C,
and the resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature for 2 h.
Benzylbromide (1.71 g, 10 mmol) was added to the residue. The resulting
solution was stirred at room temperature for another 4 h. The solvent was
removed under vacuum. The product was extracted with dichloromethane
(DCM), and B1 was obtained in quantitative yield after removing the
solvent. B2 to B4 were synthesized in the same protocol with A2 to A4 as
imidazole starting materials. The products were confirmed by MS and NMR.
B1, yield 100%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Method for treating fibrosis and cancer with imidazolium and
imidazolinium compounds
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Began; Ke, Zhiyuan; Ding, Zhaobing
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2009096905 A1 2009-08-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM N-Pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7a General procedure for the synthesis
of carbonylimidazoles The phenylisocyanate (500 μL, 4.62 mmol) was
dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) at rt. The imidazole (314 mg, 4.62 mmol)
dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added to this solution, which was stirred
at rt for 1h. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The
residue was purified by recrystallisation from hexane to give the
N-pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide. Yield (856 mg, quant.). 1H NMR(300
MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 10.29 (br.s, 1H, NH), 8.40 (dd, 1H, J = 1.2, 0.9 Hz),
7.82 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5, 1.2 Hz), 7.62 (dd, 2H, J = 8.0, 1.1 Hz), 7.41 (t,
2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.18 (td, 1H, J = 8.0, 1.1 Hz), 7.09 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5,
0.9 Hz).

$DATUM Synthesis of 2-(1H-1-Imidazolyl)ethylcarbonitrile (7). A solution of
imidazole (40 g, 0.59 mol) in toluene (80 mL) was treated with
acrylonitrile (33.85 g, 0.59 mol) and Et3N (0.1 mL). The mixture was
stirred at 60-65°C for 30 h. The solvent was distilled off to afford 7.
Oil, yield 71 g, 99.75%. C6H7N3. IR spectrum (ν, cm-1): 2250 (CN). PMR
spectrum (80 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ , ppm, J/Hz): 2.69 (2H, t, J= 6.5, H-1,
propionitrile), 4.13 (2H, t, J= 6.94, H-2, propionitrile), 6.88-7.01 (2H,
m, H-4, H-5, imidazole), 7.43 (1H, s, H-1, imidazole).

$DATUM 7778-53-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: GENERAL SYNTHETIC PROCEDURE N-Heterocycles (1
mmol) and α ,β -unsaturated carbonyl compounds (1.2 mmol) were added to a
10-mL flask containing anhydrous K3PO4 (0.25 mmol), and the mixture was
stirred at room temperature for a period of time. The reaction mixture
was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure. The
residue was purified by flash-column chromatography (silica gel,
petroleum ether-ethyl acetate) to obtain the corresponding Michael
adducts. All compounds can be stored at rt for several months without
decomposition. 3-Imidazole-1-yl-propionitrile (3f) Yellow oil. Yield 99%.
1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3): δ = 2.814 (t, 2H, J=6.8 Hz), 4.268 (t, 2H, J=6.8
Hz), 7.018 (s, 1H), 7.119 (s, 1H), 7.566 (s, 1H). ESI-MS: m/z=122 (M+1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Michael addition
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild and efficient procedure for Michael addition of N-heterocycles to
α,β-unsaturated compounds using anhydrous K3PO4 as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hou, Xueling; Hemit, Helimay; Yong, Jianping; Nie, Lifei; Aisa, Haji
Akber
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2010), 40(7), 973-979

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure for the
Conjugate Addition of Imidazole to α ,β -Unsaturated Compounds: In a
typical procedure, α ,β-unsaturated compound (1.0 mmol), imidazole (1.0
mmol) and catalyst (3.6 mol%) were taken in toluene (5 mL) and stirred at
reflux temperature for 12 h. The resulting reaction mixture was filtered
and washed with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL) and concentrated under reduced pressure.
The crude product was purified by column chromatography to afford the
pure product. All the products gave satisfactory NMR data and mass
spectral data.12a,29 Table 2 Entry 1, yield 98%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cellulose-supported copper(0) catalyst for aza-Michael addition
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Reddy, K. Rajender; Kumar, Nadakudity S.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2006), (14), 2246-2250

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 872-50-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Experimental Procedure. A 50-mL thermostated
reactor fitted with overhead stirrer (H.E.L auto-MATE) was charged with
K2CO3 (7.26 g, 52.5 mmol), CuCl (0.25 g, 2.5 mmol) and 10 mL of NMP. The
reactor was flushed with N2 and stirring was started at 500 rpm. After
addition of 50 mmol of aryl bromide, 60 mmol of amine and 6.25 mmol of
diketone ligand the mixture was heated to 130 °C under N2 and stirred for
16 h (or longer for reluctant substrates). In screening experiments a
sample of 100-200 mg was taken after this period, which was diluted with
10 mL of EtOAc and filtered over a syringe filter. Analysis was by GC
[HP5 column (30 m, id 0.32 mm, 0.25 mm film), 70-270 °C min in 10 min, 2
min at 270 °C] using dihexyl ether as internal standard. For preparative
runs the reaction mixture was partitioned between CH2Cl2 and 1N aq
NaHCO3. The organic phase was washed several times with 1 N aq NaHCO3 to
remove NMP, dried and the solvent was removed on the rotavap. The residue
was purified by flash chromatography on silica (heptane-EtOAc 15:5).
Table 2. Entry 6, yield 99%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Aromatic amination of aryl bromides catalyzed by copper/β-diketone
catalysts: the effect of concentration
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM de Lange, Ben; Lambers-Verstappen, Marielle H.; Schmieder-van de
Vondervoort, Lizette; Sereinig, Natascha; de Rijk, Ron; de Vries, Andre
H. M.; de Vries, Johannes G.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2006), (18), 3105-3109

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure: A mixture of
4-bromotoluene (1 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol) and
Cu(II)-NaY (100 mg) in DMF (3 mL) was heated to 120 °C for the specified
time (Table 2). The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC or TLC.
The reaction mixture was filtered to separate the catalyst and the
filtrate was quenched with aq NaHCO3 and the product extracted with
EtOAc. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over
Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue was purified by column
chromatography to afford pure 1-(4-methylphenyl)-1H-imidazole. Table 2
Entry 5, yield 99%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Cu(II)-NaY zeolite catalyst used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 98
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 30754-24-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides. A
Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are charged with a magnetic
stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg, 0.20 mmol, 20 mol %),
and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08 mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1
mL) was added at room temperature. Then a solution of bromobenzene (188
mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0 mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added.
The tube was sealed and the mixture was allowed to stir for 24 h at
110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction mixture after completion of
the reaction. Then it was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and
the combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4 and
concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by column chromatography
on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as eluant, to give an oil
of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%) 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (4a), yield
(164 mg, 98%) 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.87(s, 1H), 7.51-7.46 (m, 2H),
7.40 -7.34 (m, 3H), 7.29 (br s, 1H), 7.21 (br s, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz) δ
137.1, 135.5, 130.1, 129.7, 127.4, 121.3, 118.2. GC-MS m/z 144.0 (M+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on solvents, catalysts and ligands, optimization study, sealed
tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host

$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (5)5d, yield 98%. 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.88 (s, 1 H), 7.53-7.47 (m, 2 H), 7.41-7.36 (m, 3 H),
7.30 (s, 1 H), 7.22 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.4, 135.6,
130.4, 129.9, 127.7, 121.5, 118.3. LRMS (EI, 70 eV): m/z (%) = 144 (M+,
100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (11), 1707-1716

$DATUM 935547-42-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for the Catalytic N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a
magnetic stirring bar was charged with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand
(0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle
(1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under
N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the system was
then evacuated twice and back filled with N2. The reaction mixture was
stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24
h. The reaction mixture was then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted
with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a plug of silica gel, and
washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and
the resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel
to provide the desired product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 Following
the general procedure, imidazole (0.068 g, 1.0 mmol) was coupled with
bromobenzene (126 μL, 1.2 mmol) in the presence of ligand 4a. The crude
product was purified over a silica gel column using ethyl acetate/petrol
ether (1/1) to give pale yellow oil (96% yield). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3):
δ 7.25 (s, 1 H), 7.32 (s, 1H), 7.38-7.41 (m, 3H), 7.49-7.51 (m, 2H), 7.92
(s, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 118.3, 121.5, 127.5, 129.9,
130.3, 135.7, 137.3 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 144 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on catalysts, solvents and reaction conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM reaction products with sodium hydroxide and L-proline
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 960243-04-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):AMD
$DATUM polystyrene-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl
Halides. A flamedried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with CuI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), 4a-2 (145 mg, 0.1 mmol of the
L-proline unit), K2CO3 (165 mg, 1.2 mmol), nitrogen-containing
heterocycle (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (0.6 mmol), and DMSO (2
mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the
system was then evacuated three times and backfilled with N2. The
reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then
heated at 120 °C for 60 h. The resulting mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired product.
2-(1H-imidazolyl)pyridine (6o)3 Following the general procedure,
imidazole (0.034 g, 0.5 mmol) was coupled with 2-bromopyridine (59 µL,
0.6 mmol). The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using
ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give pale yellow oil (99% yield) . 1H
NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (bs, 1H), 7.14-7.17 (m, 1 H), 7.26 (d, J =
8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.53 (s, 1H), 7.71-7.77 (m, 1H), 8.28 (bs, 1H), 8.39 (2d, J
= 1.4, 1.5 Hz, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 112.3, 116.1, 121.5,
122.0, 130.6, 135.0, 139.0, 149.1 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 145 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst (polymer-supported ionic liq.-copper complex)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Concept of Supported Amino Acid Ionic Liquids and Their Application in
Metal Scavenging and Heterogeneous Catalysis
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chen, Wen; Zhang, Yuanyuan; Zhu, Liangbo; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129(45), 13879-13886

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
2-(1H-imidazolyl)pyridine (3n) 2 Following the general procedure, pale
yellow oil was obtained (98% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (bs,
1H), 7.14-7.17 (m, 1 H), 7.26 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.53 (s, 1H),
7.71-7.77 (m, 1H), 8.28 (bs, 1H), 8.39 (2d, J = 1.4, 1.5 Hz, 1H) ppm. 13C
NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 112.3, 116.1, 121.5, 122.0, 130.6, 135.0, 139.0,
149.1 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 145 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A
flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged
with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand (0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0
mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl
halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced
with a glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back
filled with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room
temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was
then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 2-(1H-imidazolyl)pyridine (7p) 2
Following the general procedure, imidazole (0.068 g, 1.0 mmol) was
coupled with 2-bromopyridine (117 μL, 1.2 mmol) in the presence of ligand
4a. The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using ethyl
acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give pale yellow oil (98% yield) . 1H NMR
(300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (bs, 1H), 7.14-7.17 (m, 1 H), 7.26 (d, J = 8.2
Hz, 1H), 7.53 (s, 1H), 7.71-7.77 (m, 1H), 8.28 (bs, 1H), 8.39 (2d, J =
1.4, 1.5 Hz, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 112.3, 116.1, 121.5,
122.0, 130.6, 135.0, 139.0, 149.1 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 145 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-614-CAS-26571040
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 3-[Tris(pentafluorophenyl)borane]-1H-Imidazole (17). A colorless solution
of imidazole (0.31 g, 4.50 mmol) in 5 mL of dichloromethane was added at
room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere to a light yellow solution of
tris(pentafluorophenyl) borane (2.33 g, 4.55 mmol) in 13 mL of
dichloromethane in a 25 mL Schlenk flask. During the addition the color
of the solution turned from light yellow to yellow. Exothermicity was not
observed. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature,
and then the solvent was evaporated in vacuo to give a white powder as
product (2.60 g, 99.6%): 3-[Tris(pentafluorophenyl)borane]-1H-Imidazole
(17), yield 99.6%, 2.60 g. mp 214.9-217.8 °C; 1H NMR (C6D6) δ 5.49 (t,
1H, J = 1.76 Hz, H5), 6.30 (bs, 1H, H4), 6.66 (bs, 1H, H2), 7.24 (bs, 1H,
NH); NOESY (C6D6) δ1/δ17.24/6.66 (NH/H2), 7.24/ 5.49 (NH/H5), 6.30/5.49
(H4/H5); 1H NMR (CD2Cl2) δ 7.18-7.24 (m, 2H, H4 and H5), 8.08 (bs, 1H,
H2), 10.05 (bs, 1H, NH); 13C NMR (CD2Cl2) δ 117.81 (C5), 126.66 (C4),
136.22 (C2).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthesis and Reactivity of (C6F5)3B-N-Heterocycle Complexes. 1.
Generation of Highly Acidic sp3 Carbons in Pyrroles and Indoles

$DATUM 121-44-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM N-(3-Methoxycarbonyl)benzylimidazole. Imidazole (3.8 g, 55.8 mmol) and
methyl 3-bromomethyl-benzoate (3.1 g, 13.5 mmol) were combined in 4 mL of
DMF. The resulting faint yellow solution was stirred at room temperature
for 20 h. Upon completion, the reaction was diluted with 60 mL of water
and extracted 3× with a total of 120 mL CH2Cl2. The organic layer was
collected and extracted 3× with a total of 150 mL of a 10% HCl solution.
The acidic solution was then alkalized with triethylamine to pH ) 10,
extracted 3× with a total of 210 mL ethyl acetate followed by drying over
Na2SO4. Rotary evaporation of the solvent yielded a faint-yellow oil in
quantitative amounts. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): 7.99 (d, 1H), 7.88 (s,
1H), 7.56 (s, 1H), 7.41 (t, 1H), 7.32 (d, 1H), 7.01 (s, 1H), 6.89 (s,
1H), 5.16 (s, 2H), 3.91 (s, 3H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Iron-Porphyrin NO Complexes with Covalently Attached N-Donor Ligands:
Formation of a Stable Six-Coordinate Species in Solution
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Berto, Timothy C.; Praneeth, V. K. K.; Goodrich, Lauren E.; Lehnert,
Nicolai
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131(47), 17116-17126

$DATUM Step B. The alkylation was carried out according to the method described
in ref 19 using the ω-chloro instead of the ω-bromoalkyl compound as the
alkylating agent. The resulting tert-butyl-3- chloropropylmethylcarbamate
24 was reacted with a solution of HCl in 1,4-dioxane (4 M, 20 mL) at 0
°C. After the complete deprotection, the organic solvent was removed
under vacuum and the resulting precipitate was used without further
purification [imidazole (0.14 g, 2.0 mmol, 1.1 equiv), sodium hydride

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 2. General procedure for synthesis of nucleotide imidazolide
derivatives. GMP-lm, m27,2'-OGMP-lm, GDP-lm, and m27,2'-OGDP-lm were
prepared as described by T. Mukaiyama et al., "Phosphorylation by
oxidation-reduction condensation. Preparation of active phosphorylating
reagents," M. Bull. Chem. Soc. Jpn., vol. 44, p. 2284 (1971). The
nucleotide (1 equiv., TEA salt), imidazole (8 equiv.), and 2,2'-
dithiodipyridine (3 equiv.) were mixed in DMF (∼2.5 ml/100 mg of
nucleotide). Triethylamine (2 equiv.) and triphenylphosphine (3 equiv.)
were added, and the mixture was stirred for 6-8 h.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Production of
1-(7-imidazol-1-yl-4-methyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrobenzo[e][1,4]diazepin-1-yl)ethanone
1-(7-Bromo-4-methyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrobenzo[e][1,4]diazepin-1-yl)ethanone
(3 g, 10.6 mM) was dissolved in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) (20 ml). To
the solution, imidazole (1 g, 14.7 mM), copper (I) iodide (0.2 g, 1.1
mM), N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (0.45 ml, 4.2 mM), and cesium carbonate
(7 g, 21.5 mM) were added, and the mixture was heated with stirring at
150°C for 8 hours. After the completion of the reaction, the solvent was
distilled off from the reaction mixture, and water was added to the
mixture. Extraction with dichloromethane was performed, and the extract
was dried over sodium sulfate. The solvent was distilled off under
reduced pressure from the reaction mixture to obtain
1-(7-imidazol-1-yl-4-methyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrobenzo[e][1,4]diazepin-1-yl)ethanone
in a brown solid form (2.9 g, yield: quantitative).
1-(7-imidazol-1-yl-4-methyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrobenzo[e][1,4]diazepin-1-yl)ethanone,
yield (2.9 g, quantitative). 1H-NMR (CDCl3) δ ppm : 1.92(s, 3H), 2.39(s,
3H), 2.87-2.99(m, 3H), 3.57(d, J=13.9Hz, 1H), 3.78(d, J=13.9Hz, 1H),
4.60-4.69(m, 1H), 6.90-8.00(m, 5H), 8.45(s, 1H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Substituted benzo[1,4]diazepine derivatives as antidepressants and their
preparation
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Sasaki, Hirofumi; Tai, Kuninori; Arai, Kenta; Shinohara, Tomoichi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2009145357 A1 2009-12-03

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of activated monomers. The
corresponding phosphoimidazolide activated monomers (ImpN, 2-MeImpN,
2,4-diMeImpN and 2-AbzImpN where N=U, C, G, A or I; see structures in
Figure 1) were synthesized in our laboratory by oxidative condensation of
the imidazolide and the nucleoside 5′monophosphate in anhydrous solvents.
The monomer preparations were 96 to 98% pure and were obtained in
practically quantitative yield. These nucleotide derivatives are solids,
very stable under dry/cold conditions and relatively stable under
dry/room temp. conditions. The procedure for the synthesis of the sodium
salt of 2-MeImpG is detailed below: 5′-GMP free acid, 0.46 g (1.25 mmol),
and 1.64 g (20 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved with stirring in
10 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Four
hundred mL of freshly distilled triethylamine was added, followed by 1.05
g (4 mmol) of triphenylphosphine and 0.88 g (4 mmol) of
2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide. The mixture was stirred for 1 h under argon and
quenched by adding it dropwise with stirring to a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask
cooled at 0°C. containing 50 mL of acetone, 50 mL of anhydrous ether, and
4 mL of a saturated sodium perchlorate/acetone solution. Sodium was
replaced by lithium perchlorate for the synthesis of the corresponding
lithium salt. The mixture was stirred for 20 min to allow precipitation
and the product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed three times
with 1:1 acetone: ether and three times with acetone. The product was
dried under reduced pressure and purified if necessary by dissolving it
in DMSO and reprecipitating as described above. Derivatized Nucleotide:
inosine-5′-monophosphate-imidazolide
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, product further converted into sodium or lithium salt,
alternative preparation shown, no experimental detail
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Non-enzymatic large scale synthesis of RNA
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kanavarioti, Anastassia; Deamer, David W.; Monnard, Pierre-Alain M.;
Bernasconi, Claude F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2002068674 A2 2002-09-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure for the
Conjugate Addition of Imidazole to α ,β -Unsaturated Compounds: In a
typical procedure, α ,β-unsaturated compound (1.0 mmol), imidazole (1.0
mmol) and catalyst (3.6 mol%) were taken in toluene (5 mL) and stirred at
reflux temperature for 12 h. The resulting reaction mixture was filtered
and washed with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL) and concentrated under reduced pressure.
The crude product was purified by column chromatography to afford the
pure product. All the products gave satisfactory NMR data and mass
spectral data.12a,29 Table 2 Entry 3, yield 98%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cellulose-supported copper(0) catalyst for aza-Michael addition

$DATUM Reddy, K. Rajender; Kumar, Nadakudity S.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2006), (14), 2246-2250

imidazole (50 mg, 0.72 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (234 mg, 0.72 mmol) were taken

$DATUM 2.10. Synthesis of IMS-DDImBr. NaOH (12.50 g, 312.5 mmol) was dissolved
in water (12.50 g) and mixed with THF (60 mL). Imidazole (1.31 g, 19.8
mmol) and TBAB (0.606 g, 1.98 mmol) were added at 25 °C until all the
solids were dissolved, prior to adding 1-bromododecane (4.65 g, 18.64
mmol) and heating to 60 °C for 16 h. Upon cooling, THF was removed by
rotary evaporation, and the product was extracted three times with DCM.
The organic layer was dried with magnesium sulfate, and the filtrate was
concentrated by rotary evaporation. 2-dodecyl-1H-imidazole 6. Oil,
quantitative yield. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.44 (s, 1H, -N-CH-N-), δ 7.03 (s,
1H, -N-CH═CH-N-), δ 6.88 (s, 1H, -N-CH═CH-N-), δ 3.90 (t, 2H,
N-CH2-CH2-), δ 1.75 (t, 2H, N-CH2-CH2-), δ 1.24 (m, 18H), δ 0.86 (t, 3H,
-CH2-CH2 -CH3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Ionomeric Elastomers

$DATUM (1R,2S,5R)-2-Isopropyl-5-methylcyclohexyl 1H-imidazole-1-carboxylate
(12c) To a solution of imidazole (1.36 g, 20 mmol) in THF (40 mL) was
added (-)-menthyl chloroformate (2.14 ml, 10 mmol) dropwise at 0 °C. The
resulting solution was stirred at rt overnight before it was filtered
under a stream of N2. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford
12c (2.50 g, quant. yield) as a colorless oil, which was used directly in
the N-carbamoylation reaction of oxindoles. [α]D23.2 = -84.9o (CHCl3, c =
3.73). IR (film) λmax/cm-1: 2957, 2871, 1755, 1393, 1290, 1240, 1002. 1H
NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.11 (brs, 1H), 7.40 (brs, 1H), 7.04 (brs, 1H),
4.86(td, 11.0, 4.4, 1H), 2.14(dm, 11.7, 1H), 1.89(quintet of d, 7.1, 2.6,
1H), 1.75-1.69(m, 2H), 1.56-1.50(m, 2H), 1.18-1.05(m, 2H), 0.92(dd, 10.0,
6.8, 8H), 0.79(d, 6.8, 3H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ 148.3, 137.1,
130.5, 117.2, 79.4, 47.0, 40.6, 34.0, 31.4, 26.5, 23.5, 21.9.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1N-diphenylmethyl-3-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl-azetidine A solution of the
title compound from Step C (2.3 g, 6.95 mmoles) in DMF (15 mL) was added
to a stirred solution of NaH (0.25 g, 10.42 mmoles) and imidazole (0.71
g, 10.44 mmoles) in DMF (10 mL) under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture
was stirred at 60°C. for 16 h. DMF was evaporated in vacuo. The resulting
crude product was extracted with CH2Cl2 and the extract was successively
washed with water and brine, and the CH2Cl2 was evaporated to leave the
title compound. Yield 2.1 g, 100%. FABMS (M+1) = 304.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
2-(1H-1-imidazolyl)pyrimidine 7) 2-(1H-1-imidazolyl)pyrimidine (Table 1,
entry 7). M.p. 124 °C ; 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ=8.68 (d, 2H, J = 4.5
Hz), 8.58 (br s, 1H), 7.84 (br s, 1H), 7.18 (t, 1H, J = 4.5 Hz), 7.03 (br
s, 1H); EI-MS: 146 (100%), 119, 92, 79, 53; GC/MS: tR = 17.19min; m/z :
146.15.; HRMS: calcd.for C7H6N4 .146.059, found 146.059; IR: (KBr) cm-1;
3142.13, 1610.12, 1570.06, 1446.03, 1313.58, 1053.72, 751.76, 650.89.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes

$DATUM Ia. Synthesis of the imidazolium salts
1-(2-Iodobenzyl)-3-methylimidazolium iodide. NaH (0.76 g, 60% in mineral
oil, 16 mmol) was added at room temperature to a stirred solution of
imidazole 0.73 g (10.7 mmol) in DMF (45 mL). After 5 min a solution of
2-iodobenzyl methanesulfonate (5.0 g, 16 mmol in DMF, 20 mL) was added.
The mixture was stirred overnight at r.t., hydrolyzed with water (50 mL)
and extracted with CH2Cl2. 1-(2-iodobenzyl)imidazole was obtained in
quantitative yield (3.0 g) after column chromatography with CH2Cl2/EtOH
9:1 as the eluent. 1-(2-iodobenzyl)imidazole, quantitative yield (3.0 g)
1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 5.14 (s, 2H, NCH2), 6.84 (dd, 3 J= 7.5 Hz, J=
1.5 Hz, 1H, Ar), 6.92 (br s, 1H), 7.01 (td, 3 J ~ 7.5 Hz, J= 1.8 Hz, 1H,
Ar), 7.10 (br s, 1H), 7.30 (td, 3 J ~7.5 Hz, J= 1.2 Hz, 1H, Ar), 7.57 (br
s, 1H), 7.86 (dd, 3 J= 8.0 Hz, J= 1.2 Hz, 1H, Ar); 13C NMR (75 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 55.5 (NCH2), 98.1 (C-I), 119.4 (NCH=), 128.5, 128.9, 129.8
(NCH=), 130.0, 137.7 (NCHN), 138.6 (C), 139.8 (CH) ppm. HRMS (ESI) calcd.
for C10H9N2I.H: 284.9889. Found: 284.9880.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for preparation of N-Boc
amines and amine derivatives: The amine or diamine (1 mmol) was added to
a magnetically stirred mixture of Amberlyst-15 (7-10% w/w) and
di-tert-butyl dicarbonate (1.1-2.5 mmol) in 1 cm3 EtOH at room
temperature. After completion of the reaction (followed by TLC), the
catalyst was separated by filtration. The filtrate was concentrated on a
rotary evaporator to afford the corresponding pure product. If necessary,
the product was further purified either by recrystallization or silica
gel column chromatography with EtOAc-hexane (1:6) as eluent. In the cases
where excess (Boc)2O was used, the crude products were washed with
n-hexane or petroleum ether before further purification. Compound 22,
yield 100%. Mp. 46-48/42-45 °C.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, reusable catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

acids, and peptides under heterogeneous conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 2 General Procedure for Nucleotide Imidazolide Derivatives
(GMP-Im, m 2 7,2′-O GMP-Im, GDP-Im, and m 2 7,2′-O GDP-Im) (7, 8, and
12-15) See T. Mukaiyama, et al. “Phosphorylation by oxidation-reduction
condensation. Preparation of active phosphorylating reagents”, M. Bull.
Chem. Soc. Jpn, vol. 44, 2284 (1971). An appropriate nucleotide (1 eq.
TEA salt), imidazole (8 eq.), and 2,2′-dithiodipyridine (3 eq.) were
mixed in DMF (approx. 2.5 ml/100 mg of nucleotide). Triethylamine (2 eq.)
and triphenylphosphine (3 eq.) were added, and the mixture was stirred
for 6-8 h. The product was precipitated from the reaction mixture with
anhydrous sodium perchlorate (1 eq. per one negative charge) dissolved in
dry acetone (approx. 8 ml/1 ml of DMF). After cooling to 4° C. the
precipitate was filtered, washed repeatedly with cold, dry acetone, and
dried in vacuum over P4O10. Yields were 80-100%. In case of m 7 GMP, due
to its lower solubility in DMF, 2-fold larger excess of reagents was
used, and reaction time was extended to 24 h.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthesis and use of anti-reverse phosphorothioate analogs of the
messenger RNA cap
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
1-(4-Trifluoromethyl-2-cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole 4)
1-(4-Trifluoromethyl-2-cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 1, entry 4). M.p.
68 °C ; 1H NMR (300 MHz ,CDCl3): δ=8.1(d, 1H, J = 2.26Hz), 8.01 (dd, 1H,
J = 2.26, 8.30Hz), 7.95( br s, 1H), 7.64 (d, 1H, J = 8.30 Hz), 7.42( br
s, 1H), 7.32 (br s, 1H), 7.23 (br s, 1H); EI-MS: 237 (100%), 210, 183,
170; GC/MS: tR = 19.25 min; m/z : 237.20; HRMS: calcd.for C11H6N3F3
.237.051, found 237.050.; IR (KBr) cm-1 3083.11, 2233.47, 1616.81,
1519.06, 1338.65, 1176.64, 1049.21, 734.84.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Gopaldasu T.; Sreedhar, Bojja
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127(28), 9948-9949

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 3-((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)-5-bromo-2-methoxypyridine A solution of
5-bromo-3-(chloromethyl)-2-methoxypyridine (526 mg, 2.224 mmol),
1H-imidazole (454 mg, 6.67 mmol), and potassium carbonate (1537 mg, 11.12
mmol) in acetonitrile (20 mL) was maintained at 80°C for 6 hours. The
mixture was cooled to room temperature and diluted with ethyl acetate and
water. The organic layer was separated, dried over sodium sulfate,
filtered, concentrated, and purified by column chromatography to afford
3-((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)-5-bromo-2-methoxypyridine. White solid,
yield (596 mg, 2.223 mmol, 100 %).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM [0071] Imidazole (46.5 g) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (500 ml) under
a nitrogen flow, and added dropwise with 3-ethoxypropionyl chloride (46,7
g), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 hour. The salt
produced in the reaction mixture was separated by filtration, and the
resulting residue was concentrated and dried under reduced pressure to
synthesize Compound 10 as the target compound (67.61 g, quantitative
yield).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-031-CAS-8285976
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1310-73-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-[2'-(2''-Methoxyethoxy)ethyl]imidazole (1). A mixture of imidazole
(2.04 g, 30 mmol), NaOH 50% solution (2.88 g, 30 mmol) in THF (35 mL) and
2-(2'-methoxyethoxy)ethyl p-toluenesulfonate (8.23 g, 30 mmol) was
refluxed for 2 days. After cooling and removal of all solvents under
vacuum, the mixture was extracted 3 times with CH2Cl2/H2O. The combined
organic layer was washed with water and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The
drying agent was removed by filtration and the solvent was removed in a
rotoevaporator. A yellow liquid (5.22 g, 100%) was obtained after drying
in a N2 stream. 1-[2'-(2''-Methoxyethoxy)ethyl]imidazole (1), yield (5.22
g, 100%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 23 °C): δ 3.37 (s, 3H), 3.51 (m, 2H),
3.57 (m, 2H), 3.74 (t, J = 5, 2H), 4.12 (t, J = 5, 2H), 6.99 (s, 1H),
7.04 (s, 1H), 7.53 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, 23 °C): δ 46.9,
59.0, 70.5, 70.6, 71.7, 119.3, 129.1, 137.4. The 1H NMR spectral data are
exactly the same as reported in the literature.31
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Ion Conduction in Imidazolium Acrylate Ionic Liquids and their Polymers
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Lee, Minjae; Choi, U. Hyeok; Colby, Ralph H.; Gibson, Harry W.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Chemistry of Materials (2010), 22(21), 5814-5822

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-Pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7a General
procedure for the synthesis of carbonylimidazoles The phenylisocyanate
(500 μL, 4.62 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) at rt. The imidazole
(314 mg, 4.62 mmol) dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added to this
solution, which was stirred at rt for 1h. The resulting mixture was
concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by recrystallisation from
hexane to give the N-pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide.
N-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7c. 7c was obtained from
the corresponding isocyanate in quantitative yield (1 g) following the
general procedure. 1H NMR(300 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 10.16 (br.s, 1H, NH),
8.37 (dd, 1H, J = 1.3, 0.8 Hz), 7.80 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5, 1.3 Hz), 7.50 (d,
2H, J = 8.5 Hz), 7.08 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5, 0.8 Hz), 6.98 (d, 2H, J = 8.5
Hz), 3.76 (s, 3H, CH3).

$DATUM 56428-57-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-614-CAS-30157881
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of activated monomers. The
corresponding phosphoimidazolide activated monomers (ImpN, 2-MeImpN,
2,4-diMeImpN and 2-AbzImpN where N=U, C, G, A or I; see structures in
Figure 1) were synthesized in our laboratory by oxidative condensation of
the imidazolide and the nucleoside 5′monophosphate in anhydrous solvents.
The monomer preparations were 96 to 98% pure and were obtained in
practically quantitative yield. These nucleotide derivatives are solids,
very stable under dry/cold conditions and relatively stable under
dry/room temp. conditions. The procedure for the synthesis of the sodium
salt of 2-MeImpG is detailed below: 5′-GMP free acid, 0.46 g (1.25 mmol),
and 1.64 g (20 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved with stirring in
10 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Four
hundred mL of freshly distilled triethylamine was added, followed by 1.05
g (4 mmol) of triphenylphosphine and 0.88 g (4 mmol) of
2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide. The mixture was stirred for 1 h under argon and
quenched by adding it dropwise with stirring to a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask
cooled at 0°C. containing 50 mL of acetone, 50 mL of anhydrous ether, and
4 mL of a saturated sodium perchlorate/acetone solution. Sodium was
replaced by lithium perchlorate for the synthesis of the corresponding
lithium salt. The mixture was stirred for 20 min to allow precipitation
and the product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed three times
with 1:1 acetone: ether and three times with acetone. The product was
dried under reduced pressure and purified if necessary by dissolving it
in DMSO and reprecipitating as described above. Derivatized Nucleotide:
uridine-5′-monophosphate-imidazolide
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, product further converted into sodium or lithium salt,
alternative preparation shown, no experimental detail
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Non-enzymatic large scale synthesis of RNA
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kanavarioti, Anastassia; Deamer, David W.; Monnard, Pierre-Alain M.;
Bernasconi, Claude F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2002068674 A2 2002-09-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 8 Yield: 100% 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.49–7.45 (m, 2H), 7.39–7.34 (m, 3H), 7.28 (s, 1H),
7.21 (s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR (100.6 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.4, 135.7, 130.5,
130.0 (2C), 127.6, 121.5 (2C), 118.3 ppm; GC/MS (EI) m/z (%): 145 (11),
144 (100), 117 (47), 90 (36), 89 (12), 77 (28), 51 (16); IR (thin film,
neat) cm-1: 3118, 1598, 1509, 1304, 1252, 1110, 1059, 908, 760, 689, 661,
520.

Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture of aryl halide (1 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O (0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol)
and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature specified under Ar
atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl halide as monitored
by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned between ethyl acetate
(10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL). The combined
organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and
concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl acetate/methanol
as eluent. The desired product. Characterization data of two
representative products are shown as follows: (a) 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole
(Table 1, entry 2), a light yellow liquid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
7.85 (s, 1H), 7.49–7.45 (m, 2H), 7.39–7.34 (m, 3H), 7.28 (s, 1H), 7.21
(s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR (100.6 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.4, 135.7, 130.5, 130.0
(2C), 127.6, 121.5 (2C), 118.3 ppm; GC/MS (EI) m/z (%): 145 (11), 144
(100), 117 (47), 90 (36), 89 (12), 77 (28), 51 (16); IR (thin film, neat)
cm-1: 3118, 1598, 1509, 1304, 1252, 1110, 1059, 908, 760, 689, 661, 520.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative catalysts (Cu,CuO),bases (Cs2CO3,K3PO4,K2CO3) and solvent
(DMSO) gave lower yield, alternative reaction conditions shown, no
reaction in absence of catalyst, optimization study, optimized on
catalyst,base,temperature,solvent, recovered catalyst gave comparable
yield
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu2O: a Simple and Efficient Reusable Catalyst for N-arylation of
Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure: A mixture of
4-bromotoluene (1 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol) and
Cu(II)-NaY (100 mg) in DMF (3 mL) was heated to 120 °C for the specified
time (Table 2). The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC or TLC.
The reaction mixture was filtered to separate the catalyst and the
filtrate was quenched with aq NaHCO3 and the product extracted with
EtOAc. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over
Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue was purified by column
chromatography to afford pure 1-(4-methylphenyl)-1H-imidazole. Table 2
Entry 9, yield 99%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Cu(II)-NaY zeolite catalyst used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 98
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 429-41-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 66-71-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (5)5d, yield 98%. 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.88 (s, 1 H), 7.53-7.47 (m, 2 H), 7.41-7.36 (m, 3 H),
7.30 (s, 1 H), 7.22 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.4, 135.6,
130.4, 129.9, 127.7, 121.5, 118.3. LRMS (EI, 70 eV): m/z (%) = 144 (M+,
100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Arylation of
Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Halides. To a solution of CH3ONa
(3.0 mmol)in DMSO (3 mL) was added CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) and ligand (0.2
mmol). After stirring at room temperature for 30 min, a mixtureof halide
(2.0 mmol) and nitrogen-containing heterocycle (2.0mmol) in 2 mL of DMSO
was added to the flask, and the reaction mixture was stirred at the
indicated temperature for the corresponding reaction time. The mixture
was cooled to room temperature,10 mL of water was added, and the
resulting suspension was extracted with ethyl acetate (4 x 10 mL). The
extraction was dried over MgSO4, then concentrated and purified by column
chromatography on silica gel. Yield 98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
7.82 (br, 1H), 7.43-7.39 (m, 2H), 7.32-7.18 (m, 5H) 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 137.18, 129.93, 129.57, 127.15, 121.11LRMS (EI, 20 eV) m/z
(%) 144 (M+, 100)

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for Cu-catalyzed amination:
A mixture of aryl iodides (0.5 mmol), amine (0.75 mmol), Cs2CO3 (1.0
mmol), CuBr (0.05 mmol), ligand L2 (0.06 mmol) in 0.5 mL of DMSO was
heated at the indicated temperature for the specified time and then
allowed to cool to room temperature. Ethyl acetate (3 ml) and water (3
ml) were then added to the reaction mixture. The mixture was partitioned
between water and ethyl acetate. The organic phase was separated, and the
aqueous phase was further extracted with ethyl acetate (4 x 5 ml). The
combined organic phase was wash with brine, dried over MgSO4, and
concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on
silica gel. N-(Phenyl)benzylamine3(Table 2, entry 1, pages S33-S34)
N-Phenylimidazole5 (Table 3, entry 1, pages S73-S74) Yellow oil. 1H NMR
(CDCl3) δ 7.79 (s, 1H), 7.39-7.43 (m, 2H), 7.28-7.32 (m, 3H), 7.29 (s,
1H), 7.15 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ 137.3, 135.5, 130.3, 129.8, 127.4,
121.4, 118.2.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of activated monomers. The
corresponding phosphoimidazolide activated monomers (ImpN, 2-MeImpN,
2,4-diMeImpN and 2-AbzImpN where N=U, C, G, A or I; see structures in
Figure 1) were synthesized in our laboratory by oxidative condensation of
the imidazolide and the nucleoside 5′monophosphate in anhydrous solvents.
The monomer preparations were 96 to 98% pure and were obtained in
practically quantitative yield. These nucleotide derivatives are solids,
very stable under dry/cold conditions and relatively stable under
dry/room temp. conditions. The procedure for the synthesis of the sodium
salt of 2-MeImpG is detailed below: 5′-GMP free acid, 0.46 g (1.25 mmol),
and 1.64 g (20 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved with stirring in
10 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Four
hundred mL of freshly distilled triethylamine was added, followed by 1.05
g (4 mmol) of triphenylphosphine and 0.88 g (4 mmol) of
2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide. The mixture was stirred for 1 h under argon and
quenched by adding it dropwise with stirring to a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask
cooled at 0°C. containing 50 mL of acetone, 50 mL of anhydrous ether, and
4 mL of a saturated sodium perchlorate/acetone solution. Sodium was
replaced by lithium perchlorate for the synthesis of the corresponding
lithium salt. The mixture was stirred for 20 min to allow precipitation
and the product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed three times
with 1:1 acetone: ether and three times with acetone. The product was
dried under reduced pressure and purified if necessary by dissolving it
in DMSO and reprecipitating as described above. Derivatized Nucleotide:
adenosine-5'-monophosphate-imidazolide
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, product further converted into sodium or lithium salt,
alternative preparation shown, no experimental detail
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Non-enzymatic large scale synthesis of RNA
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kanavarioti, Anastassia; Deamer, David W.; Monnard, Pierre-Alain M.;
Bernasconi, Claude F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2002068674 A2 2002-09-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-Pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7a General
procedure for the synthesis of carbonylimidazoles The phenylisocyanate
(500 μL, 4.62 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) at rt. The imidazole
(314 mg, 4.62 mmol) dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added to this
solution, which was stirred at rt for 1h. The resulting mixture was
concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by recrystallisation from
hexane to give the N-pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide.
N-p-Toly1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7b. 7b was obtained from the
corresponding isocyanate in quantitative yield (940 mg) following the
general procedure. 1H NMR(300 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 10.21 (br.s, 1H, NH),
8.38 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5, 1.2 Hz), 7.81 (dd, 1H, J = 1.2, 0.9 Hz), 7.50 (d,
2H, J = 8.5 Hz), 7.20 (d, 2H, J = 8.5 Hz), 7.08 (dd, 1H, J = 1.5, 0.9
Hz), 2.30 (s, 3H, CH3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Promiscuity and Selectivity in Covalent Enzyme Inhibition: A Systematic
Study of Electrophilic Fragments
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Joest, Christian; Nitsche, Christoph; Scholz, Therese; Roux, Lionel;
Klein, Christian D.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 57(18), 7590-7599

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Sodium Hydride (NaH) (60% in oil, 440 mg, 11 mmol) was added to a
N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of imidazole (680 mg., 10 mmol),
and the resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature for. two
hours. Subsequently, a,a'-dichloro-p-xylene (5 mmol) was added to the
residue and the solution was stirred at room temperature for another four
hours. The product was extracted from the reaction mixture using
dichloromethane (DCM) and the resultant extract was dried by using, a
vacuum to remove the solvent to obtain sample la in quantitative yield.
Sample 1a, quantitative yield. 1H NMR(CDCL3): δ 7.55 (s, 2H), 7.13 (s,
4H), 7.10 (s, 2H), 6.89 (s, 2H), 5.12 (s, 4H). MS (GC-MS): m/z 238 (M+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An antimicrobial composition
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Yugen; Liu, Lihong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2012050531 A1 2012-04-19

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of activated monomers. The
corresponding phosphoimidazolide activated monomers (ImpN, 2-MeImpN,
2,4-diMeImpN and 2-AbzImpN where N=U, C, G, A or I; see structures in
Figure 1) were synthesized in our laboratory by oxidative condensation of
the imidazolide and the nucleoside 5′monophosphate in anhydrous solvents.
The monomer preparations were 96 to 98% pure and were obtained in
practically quantitative yield. These nucleotide derivatives are solids,
very stable under dry/cold conditions and relatively stable under
dry/room temp. conditions. The procedure for the synthesis of the sodium
salt of 2-MeImpG is detailed below: 5′-GMP free acid, 0.46 g (1.25 mmol),
and 1.64 g (20 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved with stirring in
10 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Four
hundred mL of freshly distilled triethylamine was added, followed by 1.05
g (4 mmol) of triphenylphosphine and 0.88 g (4 mmol) of
2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide. The mixture was stirred for 1 h under argon and
quenched by adding it dropwise with stirring to a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask
cooled at 0°C. containing 50 mL of acetone, 50 mL of anhydrous ether, and
4 mL of a saturated sodium perchlorate/acetone solution. Sodium was
replaced by lithium perchlorate for the synthesis of the corresponding
lithium salt. The mixture was stirred for 20 min to allow precipitation
and the product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed three times
with 1:1 acetone: ether and three times with acetone. The product was
dried under reduced pressure and purified if necessary by dissolving it
in DMSO and reprecipitating as described above. Derivatized Nucleotide:
cytidine-5′-monophosphate-imidazolide
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, product further converted into sodium or lithium salt,
alternative preparation shown, no experimental detail
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Non-enzymatic large scale synthesis of RNA
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kanavarioti, Anastassia; Deamer, David W.; Monnard, Pierre-Alain M.;
Bernasconi, Claude F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2002068674 A2 2002-09-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-172-CAS-3302518
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-11-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-05-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM d) Synthesis of 4-imidazole-1-yl-6-(4-methoxy-cyclohexyl)-pyrane-2-one
4-Bromo-6-(4-methoxy-cyclohexyl)-pyrane-2-one (2.10g, 7.31 mmol) and
imidazole (1.52g, 21.95mmol) were dissolved in acetonitrile (50mL) in a
100 mL flask, and then K2CO3 (3.03g, 21.95mmol) and KI (121mg, 0.731
mmol) were added thereto. The resulting mixture was heated under reflux.
After 15 hours, the reaction solution was cooled down to room temperature
followed by filtration. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced
pressure, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on silica
gel using methylene chloride:methanol (20:1) as eluent. The fractions
containing the product were combined and evaporated to obtain a white
solid (2.01 g, 100%). 1η-NMR(CDCl3); δ =7.97(s, 1H), 7.3(s, 2H), 7.22(s,
1H), 6.19(d,1H), 6.12(d, 1H), 3.37(s, 3H), 2.65-1. 11(m, 10H).

for treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: [Mn(L)(X)2][PF6]2 [X = pyridine (Py),
4-cyanopyridine (4-NCPy), 4-aminopyridine (4-H2NPy),
4-dimethylaminopyridine (4- Me2NPy), pyrazine, imidazole (Im),
1-methylimidazole (1-MeIm), 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm) and (Ph3P)]. The
[Mn(L)(H2O)2][PF6]2 complex (0.088 g, 0.11 mmol) was dissolved in boiling
MeOH (50 cm3). An excess of X ligand was added, and the reaction mixture
was refluxed for 25 min. Addition of a concentrated MeOH solution of
(NH4)2PF6 to the hot solution gave a precipitate of the pure product,
which was collected, washed copiously with Et2O and dried in vacuo. The
yield was quantitative. Completion of the reaction could be determined by
the absence of the two H2O m(O-H) resonances in the i.r. spectrum near
3500 cm-1. Compound: [Mn(L)(Im)2][PF6]2.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation and electrochemical study of manganese(II) macrocycles
containing terpyridine

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of 1-tritylimidazole (5) To a solution of trityl chloride (5.58
g, 20.0 mmol.) in dry methylene chloride (100 ml) cooled down to 0° C.
and stirred under Ar, was added dropwise over 1.5 hours a solution of
imidazole (1.36 g, 20.0 mmol.) and triethylamine (2.7 mml, 20 mmol.) in
50 ml dry methylene chloride. At the end of the addition, the reaction
mixture was allowed to warm up to room temperature and stirred under Ar
at that temperature overnight. The reaction mixture was then washed with
20 ml of a 10% solution of ammonium chloride, then with 20 ml of
distilled water. The organic phase was dried over magnesium sulfate and
evaporated in vacuo to yield quantitatively a white solid.
Recrystallization from methylene chloride/hexanes, 5.60 g of (5)
(yield=90% after recrystallization). M.p. 214° C.; 1H NMR (200 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 7.43 (m, 1H, NCHN), 7.3-7.4 (m, 9H, 3xC6 H 5), 7.1-7.2 (m, 6H,
3xC6 H 5), 7.0 (m, 1H, Ph3 CNCH=CH), 6.81 (m, 1H, Ph3 CNCH=CH); 13C NMR
(50 MHz, CDCl3) δ 142.3, 139.0, 129.6, 128.2, 128.3, 121.6.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Method for preparing oligonucleotides with boranophosphate linkages
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Just, George; Xin, Zhili; Marsault, Eric; Jin, Yi; Wang, Jianchao;
Manoharan, Muthiah
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2000000499 A1 2000-01-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM To a solution of imidazole (2.723 g, 40 mmol) in NaOH (50% solution, 3.5
g, 44 mmol), 11-bromo-1-undecene (9.33 g, 40 mmol) and THF (20 mL) was
added and the mixture was refluxed for 2 days. After the mixture cooled,
THF was removed with a rotoevaporator. The residue was extracted with
dichloromethane/water 3 times. The combined organic layer was washed with
water and then dried over Na2SO4. The drying agent was filtered and the
filtrate was concentrated. The resultant crude 1 (8.85 g, ~100%, a yellow
oil) was used directly in the next reaction.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthesis of Precision Ionic Polyolefins Derived from Ionic Liquids

Wagener, Kenneth B.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 69281-33-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-614-CAS-27508257
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of activated monomers. The
corresponding phosphoimidazolide activated monomers (ImpN, 2-MeImpN,
2,4-diMeImpN and 2-AbzImpN where N=U, C, G, A or I; see structures in
Figure 1) were synthesized in our laboratory by oxidative condensation of
the imidazolide and the nucleoside 5′monophosphate in anhydrous solvents.
The monomer preparations were 96 to 98% pure and were obtained in
practically quantitative yield. These nucleotide derivatives are solids,
very stable under dry/cold conditions and relatively stable under
dry/room temp. conditions. The procedure for the synthesis of the sodium
salt of 2-MeImpG is detailed below: 5′-GMP free acid, 0.46 g (1.25 mmol),
and 1.64 g (20 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved with stirring in
10 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Four
hundred mL of freshly distilled triethylamine was added, followed by 1.05
g (4 mmol) of triphenylphosphine and 0.88 g (4 mmol) of
2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide. The mixture was stirred for 1 h under argon and
quenched by adding it dropwise with stirring to a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask
cooled at 0°C. containing 50 mL of acetone, 50 mL of anhydrous ether, and
4 mL of a saturated sodium perchlorate/acetone solution. Sodium was
replaced by lithium perchlorate for the synthesis of the corresponding
lithium salt. The mixture was stirred for 20 min to allow precipitation
and the product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed three times
with 1:1 acetone: ether and three times with acetone. The product was
dried under reduced pressure and purified if necessary by dissolving it
in DMSO and reprecipitating as described above. Derivatized Nucleotide:
guanosine-5′-monophosphate-imidazolide

$DATUM stereoselective, product further converted into sodium or lithium salt,
alternative preparation shown, no experimental detail

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
1-(2-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole 2) 1-(2-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table
1, entry 2). 1H NMR (300 MHz (CDCl3): δ= 7.98 (dd, H J = 1.5, 8.3 Hz),
7.7 (dt 1H J = 1.5, 7.5 Hz), 7.64-7.57 (m, 2H) 7.47 (dd, 1H J =1.5, 7.5
Hz) 7.18 (br s, 1H), 7.03(br s 1H); EI-MS: 189 (100%), 159, 141, 116, 89,
50; GC/MS: tR = 21.77 min; m/z : 189.25; HRMS: calcd.for C9H7N3O2.
189.053, found 189.053; IR: (KBr) cm-1 3103.38, 1606.83, 1523.15,
1356.61, 1058.66, 739.53, 657.61.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure. An oven-dried 25 mL round-bottomed flask with a
magnetic stirring bar was charged with CuI nanoparticles (1.25 mol %),
K2CO3 (0.1662 g, 1.2 mmol), nitrogencontaining heterocycle (1.2
mmol)/phenol (1.2 mmol), aryl chloride (1.0 mmol), and DMF (1 mL) under
air. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and
then transferred to a preheated oil bath at 110 °C. At the end of the
reaction, as judged by TLC, the reaction mixture was then cooled to room
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of EtOAc, and centrifuged to remove the
catalyst, and the catalyst was further washed with 5-10 mL of EtOAc to
make it free from organic matter. The combined organic extracts were then
concentrated under reduced pressure, and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel (60-120) using
hexane/ethyl acetate (80:20) eluent to provide the desired N-arylated/
O-arylated product. The catalyst was oven-dried at 65 °C for 2 h and
reused. 1-(2-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 2, Entry 5). Thick orange
liquid, 99%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, ppm) δ 6.82 (t, J =7.9, 8.7 Hz, 2H),
7.02 (d, J =8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.40 (t, J =8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.60-7.78 (dd, J =7.9,
1.6 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR(75MHz, CDCl3 +DMSO, ppm): δ 120.5, 121.1, 123.9,
127.4, 131.6, 132.4, 135.7, 138.4, 144.2. EI-MS: m/z = 189 (M + ). Anal.
Calcd for C9H7N3O2: C, 57.14; H,3.73; N, 22.21. Found: C, 57.12; H, 3.69;
N, 22.18.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM CuI nanoparticles used as cat..
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM CuI Nanoparticles for C-N and C-O Cross Coupling of Heterocyclic Amines
and Phenols with Chlorobenzenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Sreedhar, B.; Arundhathi, R.; Reddy, P. Linga; Kantam, M. Lakshmi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(20), 7951-7954

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 100
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7782-44-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-phenyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (IL 6). 4
Phenylboronic acid (16.0 mmol), imidazole (13.0 mmol) and copper(1)
iodide (0.6 mmol) were mixed in methanol (100 mL). The mixture solution
was refluxing 5h with pumping air continuously. Then the solvent was
evaporated under reduced pressure and extracted by ether. The extract
phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was filtered
through celite, the corresponding N-phenylimidazole was gotten in almost
quantitative yields.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An Acidity Scale of 1,3-Dialkylimidazolium Salts in Dimethyl Sulfoxide
Solution
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chu, Yuan; Deng, Hui; Cheng, Jin-Pei
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(20), 7790-7793

$DATUM 71-43-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM N-Benzoylimidazolide (13). A suspension of imidazole (4.54 g, 0.0668 mol)
in dry benzene (200 mL) was treated with a solution of benzoyl chloride
(4.69 g, 0.0333 mol) in benzene (20 mL) at 8 °C in a flask fitted with a
drying tube. The mixture was allowed to warm to room temperature and
stirred for 16 h. The precipitated imidazole hydrochloride was removed by
filtration through a fritted funnel, and the clear filtrate concentrated
under reduced pressure to give N-benzoyl imidazolide (13) as a viscous,
hygroscopic oil, yield 5.78 g, quant., which was stored at 0 °C in a
tightly stoppered vessel. 1H NMR (CDCl3) 8.05 (s, 1H), 7.78 (bd, 2H, J =
8.2 Hz), 7.67 (tt, 2H, J = 8.2, 1.5 Hz), 7.58 (bt, 1H, J = 7.4 Hz), 7.53
(bs, 1H), 7.16 (bs, 1H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

CD

$DATUM 66-71-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-(4-1H-Imidazol-1-ylphenyl)ethanone (4)5d, yield
100%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.10 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2 H), 8.02 (s, 1
H), 7.52 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 7.34 (s, 1 H), 7.27 (s, 1 H), 2.65 (s, 3
H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 196.5, 140.7, 135.9, 135.4, 130.9,
130.4, 120.8, 117.8, 26.6. LRMS (EI, 70 eV): m/z (%) = 186 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tang, Bo-Xiao; Guo, Sheng-Mei; Zhang, Man-Bo; Li, Jin-Heng
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (11), 1707-1716

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A
flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged
with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand (0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0
mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl
halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced
with a glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back
filled with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room
temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was
then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 1-(4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-ethanone
(7b)1 Following the general procedure, imidazole (0.068 g, 1.0 mmol) was
coupled with 4-bromoacetophenone (0.239 g, 1.2 mmol) in the presence of
ligand 4a. The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using
ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give a white solid (99% yield). 1H
NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.65 (s, 3H), 7.33 (bs, 1H), 7.45 (bs, 1H), 7.51
(d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.05 (bs, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR
(75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 26.6, 117.7, 120.7, 130.3, 131.1, 135.4, 135.7, 140.7,
196.5 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 186 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743
